high.name: Normalization to the maximum voluntary contraction (MVC)
high.description: Normalizing to maximum voluntary contraction (MVC) provides a relative value useful to compare the magnitude of muscle activity in different tasks or conditions. This represents the activity as a proportion of the maximum capacity of the muscle.
how_to: Conduct between 3-5 MVC that generate consistent values.
Include adequate rest periods (1-2 minutes) based on the duration of the maximal efforts.
The task executed during MVC must resemble as closely as possible to the task of interest.
caveats: If the tasks or conditions are different, each needs to be normalized separately.
Normalizing to MVC during dynamic conditions can be challenging.
Some participants may not be able to perform a true MVC.

high.name: Normalization to a standardized isometric maximum voluntary contraction (MVC)
high.description: Normalization to a standardized isometric MVC is a relative value used when it is not possible to match all aspects of the task.
how_to: Conduct between 3-5 contractions that generate consistent values.
Ensure the participant performs a true maximum.
caveats: This method is less accurate than an MVC that matches the task of interest.

caution.name: Normalization to a standardized submaximal task (isometric/ dynamic)
caution.description: Normalizing to a standardized submaximal task provides an alternative when MVC cannot be performed.
how_to: Conduct between 3-5 contractions that generate consistent values.
Include adequate rest periods based on effort duration.
caveats: Does not allow for absolute amplitude comparisons between participants.
Within-session differences can occur, so use another method for normalization.

low.name: Normalization to the peak or mean EMG amplitude during the task investigated
low.description: This method is used for comparisons within a single task across conditions but should not be used for cross-task comparisons.

low.name: Non-normalized EMG amplitude
low.description: EMG amplitude expressed in absolute units, acceptable for within-person comparisons without removing electrodes.

low.name: Normalized to the maximal M-wave amplitude
low.description: This method is mainly used for normalization of evoked potentials, but is not recommended for general muscle activity comparisons.
